content.webTitle: Full terms and conditions for the Guardian Charity Awards 2015

fields.headline: Full terms and conditions for the Guardian Charity Awards 2015
fields.bodyText: Entering the Competition 1. The Guardian Charity Awards 2015 (the “Competition”) is open to UK residents aged 18 and over who work with or for an Eligible Charity that they are nominating in the Competition (“You”), subject to paragraph 2 below. Eligible Charities must have been registered (with the Charity Commission or equivalent local regulator) in the UK for more than two years prior to June 2015 and have an annual (2014) income of between £5,000 and £1.5 million. Eligible Charities cannot have won The Guardian Charity Awards in previous years. Please see Criteria page at theguardian.com/charity-awards for further information. 2. Employees or agencies of Guardian News & Media Limited (“GNM”, “We”, the “Promoter”) its group companies or their family members, freelance contributors to GNM, or anyone else connected with the Competition may not enter the Competition. 3. By entering the Competition You are accepting these terms and conditions. 4. To enter the Competition You must follow the instructions on www.theguardian.com/charity-awards. You will be required to sign into your Guardian online account, or sign up for a Guardian online account if you do not already have one. You will then be required to provide contact details for yourself and to provide a number of pieces of information about the Eligible Charity which You are nominating. You will also be required to answer a number of questions about Your nominated Eligible Charity, providing details concerning its activities and why You believe it should win the Competition (for further information on the judging criteria please see paragraph 11 below). If You have any questions about how to enter or otherwise in connection with the Competition, please email GNM at elise.aspeling@theguardian.com with “Guardian Charity Awards” in the subject line. 5. You are responsible for the cost (if any) of sending Your Competition entry to us. 6. The Competition opens at 00:01 on 17 June 2015 and closes at 23:59 on 5 August 2015 (the “Competition Period”). Entries received outside the Competition Period will not be considered. 7. Each entrant may only submit one entry to the Competition per project. Eligible Charities will not have a greater chance of winning by virtue of submission of multiple nominations – it is the quality and content of the nominations that matters, rather than the quantity. For further information on the judging criteria and judging process, please see paragraphs 10 and 11 below. 8. You own the copyright to your Competition entry as its author. By submitting an entry to the Competition, You give GNM: a. Permission for Your entry to be published on www.theguardian.com and You grant GNM a non-exclusive, royalty-free, worldwide licence to republish Your Competition entry in electronic format and hard copy for purposes connected with the Competition; and b. The right to use Your name and town or city of residence for the sole purpose of identifying You as the author of Your entry and/or as a winner of the Competition. 9. Your entry must be Your own work, must not be copied, must not contain any third-party materials and/or content that You do not have permission to use and must not otherwise be obscene, defamatory or in breach of any applicable legislation or regulations. If We have reason to believe Your entry is not Your own work or otherwise breaches this paragraph 9, then We may not consider it. Picking the winners 10. A panel of judges will choose the five winning Eligible Charities from among those nominated. At the end of the Competition Period the Promoter will produce a long list of Eligible Charities from all entries received in accordance with these terms and conditions. A panel of expert judges will then choose the five winning Eligible Charities from those in the long list. Full details of the judging process and the names of the judges are available on request to elise.aspeling@theguardian.com 11. When choosing the long list and the five winning Eligible Charities, the Promoter and the judging panel will be looking for charitable projects that are innovative, which promote best practice, and which comprise elements that can be replicated by other charities. 12. The entrants who nominated the selected five winning Eligible Charities will be contacted by email or phone on or before 31 October 2015. If an entrant does not respond to GNM within 14 days of being notified of their charity’s win, the selected charity’s prizes will be forfeited and GNM shall be entitled to select another winning Eligible Charity in accordance with the process described above (and the relevant entrant will also have to respond to notification of their win within 14 days or else they will also forfeit their charity’s prizes). If a winning entrant or their charity rejects their prizes or the entry is invalid or in breach of these terms, the relevant prizes will be forfeited and GNM shall be entitled to select another winner. The five winning Eligible Charities, together with the names and town/city of residence of those who nominated them, will be announced on www.theguardian.com/charity-awards in December 2015. The judges’ decision is final and no correspondence will be entered into. The entrants who nominated the Eligible Charities, and the Eligible Charities themselves, must not contact, or try to contact, the judges in any way in connection with the Competition, or otherwise try to influence the judges’ selection of the winning Eligible Charities. The Prizes 13. Each of the five winning Eligible Charities will be awarded: - A minimum cash prize of £3000, kindly donated by awards partner Zurich - A 16GB WiFi only iPad Mini, courtesy of Jigsaw24 - A day of business mentoring support and training with Zurich Insurance (full details to be confirmed in due course) - One year’s membership of NCVO, free of charge (for those winning Eligible Charities that are not already an NCVO member) - A tailored package of support from the FSI - A personalised package of communications support from Media Trust - Option to attend a one day trustee training course with BWB Please see the Prizes page theguardian.com/charity-awards for further information concerning the prizes. If any additional prizes become available after 17 June 2015, full details will be announced on the Prizes page. Prizes shall be provided to the winning Eligible Charities after the awards ceremony in December. Some other rules 14. We take no responsibility for entries that are lost, delayed, misdirected or incomplete or cannot be delivered or entered for any technical or other reason. Proof of delivery of an entry is not proof of receipt. 15. Details of the winners can be obtained by sending a stamped addressed envelope to the following address after the ceremony in December 2015: The Guardian Charity Awards 2015, Elise Aspeling, Guardian News & Media Limited, Kings Place, 90 York Way, London N1 9GU. 16. No purchase is necessary. 17. The entrants who nominated the winning Eligible Charities may be required to take part in promotional activity related to the Competition and those entrants shall participate in such activity on the Promoter’s reasonable request. The entrants who nominated the winning Eligible Charities consent to the use by the Promoter and its related companies, both before and after the closing date of the Competition for an unlimited time, of the entrant’s voice, image, photograph and name for publicity purposes (in any medium, including still photographs and films, and on the internet, including any websites hosted by the Promoter and its related companies) and in advertising, marketing or promotional material without additional compensation or prior notice and, in entering the Competition, all entrants consent to the same. 18. The Promoter of the Competition is Guardian News & Media Limited whose address is Kings Place, 90 York Way, London N1 9GU. Any complaints regarding the Competition should be sent to this address. The Promoter shall use and take care of any personal information You supply to it as described in its privacy policy, a copy of which can be seen at www.theguardian.com/help/privacy-policy, and in accordance with data protection legislation. By entering the Competition, You agree to the collection, retention, usage and distribution of Your personal information in order to process and contact You about Your Competition entry, and for the purposes outlined in paragraphs 12 and 15 above. 19. Nothing in these Terms and Conditions shall exclude the liability of GNM for fraud or fraudulent misrepresentation or for death or personal injury resulting from its negligence. 20. GNM accepts no responsibility for any damage, loss, liabilities, injury or disappointment incurred or suffered by You as a result of entering the Competition or accepting any prize. GNM further disclaims liability for any injury or damage to You or any other person’s computer relating to or resulting from participation in or downloading any materials in connection with the Competition. 21. GNM reserves the right at any time and from time to time to modify or discontinue, temporarily or permanently, this Competition with or without prior notice due to reasons outside its control (including, without limitation, in the case of anticipated, suspected or actual fraud). The decision of GNM in all matters under its control is final and binding. In addition, GNM reserves the right to extend the Competition Period in the event that the entries received are of insufficient quality or quantity. 22. The specified prizes are not transferable and cannot be exchanged for cash or any other prize. GNM reserves the right to substitute the specified prizes with alternative prizes of similar value in the event that the specified prizes are unavailable. 23. GNM shall not be liable for any failure to comply with its obligations where the failure is caused by something outside its reasonable control. Such circumstances shall include, but not be limited to, weather conditions, fire, flood, hurricane, strike, industrial dispute, war, hostilities, political unrest, riots, civil commotion, inevitable accidents, supervening legislation or any other circumstances amounting to force majeure. 24. The Competition and these terms and conditions shall be governed by English law and entrants submit to the non-exclusive jurisdiction of the English Courts.
